description.text:
What is more cool than T-rex skull on your desk?
Glowing T-rex skull on your desk! Remixed version of T-Rex skull from MakerBot academy. I've added small bubble into solid part of the skull. So you can put LED diode into the skull during printing, and as the print continue the LED diode will be sealed inside forever, with only connectors reaching out of the skull. (Better photos will come soon)
(version with battery holder and on/off switch in base will be published in next few days). Please leave any questions and suggestions in the comments.

Print with natural PLA. You should get nice details even with 0.25mm layer height. 10% infill will be enough.  
Print T-RexSkull_LED.stl  
In 13% of the print, insert LED diode into the forming bubble in the center of the skull. Contacts of diode should reach out of the skull. You can pause your printer for this, but it can be done even without pausing (but be carefull not to burn your fingers while the hotend is still moving).   
Print rest of the files as normal.

Delta Printer Arm Tap Jig This jig aligns a M4 tap for cutting threads in .230" SW Pultruded Carbon Tube from www.Goodwinds.com. Visit http://www.ultibots.com for Mini Kossel V-Slot, MendelMax & UltiMax Kits, Printed Parts, Delta Components, Filament, Electronics, and More...

Print & Assemble with:
M5x20 SHCS (x2)
M5 Thumb Head (x2)
M5 Jam Nut (x2)
Drill out little hole with a M4 bit. Carefully drill big hole up to the top of the flex gap with a M6 bit. Don't drill into the little hole as it acts as a stop for the carbon tube. Carefully remove 2mm of support above the flex gap.

description.text:
The new g-code calibration script generator available at the old address:
http://elco.crsndoo.com/reprap/calibrate.html V2.0 also allow you to chose to print triangle base instead of square base so you can check the 45degree head speed (my printer for e.g. has the firmware bug where 45degree diagonal movement is sqrt(2) faster then only X or only Y movement. You can select feed and flow rate for raft base, raft interface, object, you can select layer height .. note that extruder speed will be in g-code written as value you enter * 10

• Enter values into script
  • copy/paste generated g-code into txt file
  • print the file
  • measure wall thickness
  • the wall thickness should be "layer thickness" * "perimeter width over thickness (ratio)", if the wall is thinner then target value decrease feed and/or increase flow rate. if the wall is thicker then target value increase feed rate and/or decrease flow rate (feed rate == head speed; flow rate == extruder speed)
    • repeat until you are satisfied with the result.

description.text:
TubePlotFrenet[curveList, {var, min, max}, radius_, opts___] :=
Module[{tangent, unitTangent, normal, unitNormal, biNormal},
tangent = D[curve, t];
unitTangent = tangent/Sqrt[tangent.tangent];
normal = D[unitTangent, t];
unitNormal = normal/Sqrt[normal.normal];
biNormal = Cross[unitTangent, unitNormal];
ParametricPlot3D[
curve + radius Cos[s] unitNormal + radius Sin[s] biNormal //
Evaluate, {var, min, max}, {s, 0, 2 [Pi]}, opts]]
{p0, q0} = {5, 2}; r = Cos[q0t] + 2;
x = r Cos[p0t];
y = r Sin[p0t];
z = Sin[q0t];
w0 = 8*{x, y, z}
h = TubePlotFrenet[w0, {t, 0, 2 [Pi]}, 2, Axes -> None,
Boxed -> False, PlotPoints -> {64, 16},
ColorFunction -> "CandyColors", MeshFunctions -> {#3 &}]
{p0, q0} = {2, 5}; r = Cos[q0t] + 2;
x = r Cos[p0t];
y = r Sin[p0t];
z = Sin[q0t];
w = 8{x, y, z}
h1 = TubePlotFrenet[w, {t, 0, 2 [Pi]}, 2, Axes -> None,
Boxed -> False, PlotPoints -> {64, 16},
ColorFunction -> "BeachColors", MeshFunctions -> {#3 &}]
Show[{h, h1}, PlotRange -> All, ViewPoint -> {0, 0, 5}]
ga = ParametricPlot3D[pw + (1 - p)w0, {t, -Pi, Pi}, {p, 0, 1},
Axes -> False, Boxed -> False, PlotRange -> All,
PlotPoints -> {60, 60}, ColorFunction -> "Pastel",
MeshStyle -> {Tube[0.255/4]}, PlotStyle -> {Opacity[0.0]},
ViewPoint -> {0, 0, 5}, ImageSize -> {674, 501}, Mesh -> 16]
gw = Show[{h, h1, ga}, PlotRange -> All, ViewPoint -> {0, 0, 5},
ImageSize -> 1000]

description.text:
Some shade for your toilet paper. Also can hold things like phones, books, bookmarks, other small things.  
The part that slides behind your toilet paper holder is thin. It is strong enough to hold a decent sized book and your phone without bending, but if you slip and fall in the bathroom and your head hits this thing it will break which is either a safety feature or hazard (you decide).  
Printed with standard settings with Replicator 2.

comments.text: I guess it's main purpose is the shelf part, since not many bathrooms are soaked in sun. For shelf functionality i would have made it at least leveled so things don't slide or roll off it into the toilet. Maybe even small upstanding ridges on the side, although then it might become difficult to clean which is of importance near a toilet.
comments.author: 27v0XjvQTTuRUaX6xw

comments.text: I am a dump and go person and never realized that there is any other way. I feel that time in the bathroom is wasted time. the worst time is in the fall when it gets cookin hot and I have to go number two. I come in from the sun  and have to sit there dripping sweat until it is done. hate it. and maybe you can multitask at that point but I cannot do anything but my business so I consider the whole process a waste of time and yearn to get on with making something usually. Dont get me wrong - I dont run around actively hating going to the bathroom  it is that just once the subject came up before and I had to figure out my stand on it. I embrace your design and kindly suggest the following: widen it so it is slightly wider than your TP holder, Triangle bracing on the sides that now stick out enough to do it, more rounded corners, and a lip around the top
comments.author: Shempstooges

comments.text: why do you need to shade your TP? Is your sun really strong and it disintegrates your TP on the roll? Maybe the sun heats it up and feels unpleasant when you use it? or maybe it is really a splash guard and you were to embarrassed to say?  am not being unkind it just begs to be answered - why or what for did you make this?
comments.author: Shempstooges

comments.text:
You apparently are the dump and go type of bathroom user. There is nothing wrong with this. You have things to do, places to be, and you damn well aren't going to stay in the bathroom any longer than you need to. I, on the other hand, linger in the bathroom. A potty lingererer if you will. There are often reading materials. People generally leave you alone. It is like a tiny room of contemplation, reading, cell-phone-mini-game-playing, or maybe just a quick nap. Where do you put that bookmark while reading? Where does the book go when you get that must-respond-to-text-message? Where does the phone go when all you are wearing is underpants and it is time to use your hands for other bathroom related things?
The answer? The toilet paper sun shade. Which is also a shelf.
comments.author: Shempstooges

title: Wobbless X Mounts for MakerGear Prusa

description.text:
latest version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84640
https://grabcad.com/library/wobbless-x-mounts-1 Tired of trying to align Z threaded rods and get rid of wobble I created X mounts that absorbs XY movements that Z threaded rods cause when not perfectly aligned. The absorbing structures use same principle of some lunar rover wheels. The structure uses ABS flexibility as absorber.
http://youtu.be/XAVHZ00X4DM

On Z threaded rods, to limit vertical movement of nuts it's necessary to glue and small lid over upper nut. Inside use the common nut spring nut system. The part I printed got a little bit fragile, I have to do some improvements but works great! http://youtu.be/XAVHZ00X4DM If you are having difficulties on slicing it try yo rotate the part. I also have to check out if the "ABS spring" won't break due to fatigue after a lot of prints.

comments.text:
Good job!
What is the matematical rule to obtain this spring?
I'd like to build my own in different size
comments.author: GZSA

comments.text: Thanks, I did not model this spring mathematically. The equation would have a lot of variables as wall thickness, height, total lengthand material elastic properties. Even your print parameters will change behavior. I suggest you an empirical approach, manipulating variables listed above to get the perfect spring for your application.

comments.text:
Nice DFarms. I've been using it for months, it is still working well.
If you are going to re-design it, an important improvement would be place the nuts "tap" in the lower part and re-enforce corners.
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: I think im going to embed a nut in the piece, and then tap the rest of the plastic, so i get less backlash, also im going to thicken the springs for durability.
comments.author: odudex

comments.text: You can try that, but I recommend to use the 2 nuts per rod with spring between system. About spring, I can assure you there is no sign of fatigue(white spots) on my springs. I printed them with a 0.35mm nozzle, and with this thickness the spring printed with 2 layer wall. For a bigger nozzle I would thicken proportionally. But thickening will reduce flexibility. You can also play different spring lengths and check the results.
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: I had tried using the springs before on my mendel, and they  kept binding to the threaded rods, if they had some sort of sheath it would probably be fine though, or if the spring wire is thick enough.
comments.author: odudex

comments.text: The problem you're trying to solve is because you're over-binding your threaded rods. Â Those bearings at the bottom of the machine are BAD BAD BAD. Â Take them out, and replace your rod couplers with the good aluminum ones. Â This allows the threaded rod to move in the X/Y as opposed to moving your carriage instead. Â You want the Z threaded rods to be loose so that the smooth rod can take over.
comments.author: thantik

comments.text: Â Actually the bottom bearings are not bad, if you can get straight rod and center the upper coupling - it offloads weight of the X assembly from the stepper bearings, which are not actually suited for the task.

Thantik thanks Â for the tips!I've been convinced to solve the problem on its cause.You are right about bottom bearings, I 'll remove it.
I do have aluminum couplers. In the video I was testing one side with with tubes, and it seems tube did a better job. The aluminum coupler have one issue that is: Screwing over threads, that won't allow a goodÂ alignment.Â

Updating: After releasing threaded rod from bottom bearing the spring still moves, but with a smaller amplitude. So it still acts and isÂ contributingÂ a little to increase precision.Â Of courseÂ coupling is not perfect, but it will never be
comments.author: odudex

This is another one of those things that just popped into my head and I decided to design it. I know my TARDIS is horrible, but what did you expect? One is 3d printable and one is not. The 3d printable model is less detailed, while the other is more detailed.

A scan of President George Washington played by Dennis Catafulmo, from DIRTY WORK AT THE WAX WORKS, this year's Creepshow at the Freakshow at Coney Island USA. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is my 21st century photo booth project. This is scanned with my Heavy Duty Lazy Susan for Full Body Scanning thing (see thingiverse.com/thing:28454) and ReconstructMe software (http://reconstructMe.net). I printed with 2 shells, 20% infill and support. The sword didn't turn out so great, but otherwise I'm really pleased with the result.

description.text:
My curtains kept falling because of the (not so) adhesive rod holder commonly sold in supermarket, so I designed my custom holder which lies on the top of the window.
You still need to add double-sided tape to the back of each holder, but the weight of the curtain will rely on the window, not on the adhesive.

The doors' top in my home aren't flat, so can't use the door cloth hangers sold in stores.
I made a custom cloth hanger with different types of hook to hang it to different types of doors. The cloth hanger is modular : I printed 4 blocks but you can make it longer or smaller (2 blocks minimum).

title: Weighted Holder For Electronic Cigarette, Wacom Stylus, or Sharpie

description.text:
Keep your electronic cigarette (made for joyetech ego-c, might fit others), Wacom stylus, or Sharpie close at hand with this weighted holder. 
Print both halves, fill with something heavy, then snap it together and put it on your desk!
Inventor part file included!

• Print both halves.
    The top is printed upside-down to keep the mating surface looking fine. The bottom is printed normally.

  • Fill with lead shot, screws, or anything you can find lying around that is heavier than air, small enough to fit in the cavity, but not small enough to leak out (no liquids please!)

  • The two parts should snap together fairly easily.

author: hellphish

title: Split body of the T4 Quadcopter.

description.text:
This is just an idea, there will probably be structural rigidity loss due to this simple split (i.e. no strategic reinforcing pins tying the two pieces back together). I have tried about 6 times to print the normal body out, but kept getting a shift in layers or air prints (E3D and PLA).  
Maybe Brendan22 would put his genius towards making a better two piece body if demands are high enough.
Hobbled together with Tinkercad.com

comments.text: I printed this in ABS quite some time ago and it worked. This frame is quite heavy when printed in PLA, but I have had nothing but problems with delamination on ABS prints. I've scrapped this project.
comments.author: danskinn

comments.text: Although I don't see significant structural problems in splitting this piece the way you did, I think I'll add the top plate to the upper part of the splitted body. I guess this will reinforce the upper part and the whole body.

I'd rather watch videos on my iPad than stare at a blank wall while running on the treadmill at home!

The STL files are designed specifically for the TRUE Fitness Z5 series treadmill. You can modify the clamps in blender to fit different treadmills. This stand is too big to print in one shot using a MakerBot Replicator. So, there are several pieces that fit into each other (see pictures):
  • Left half of the stand (10 hours to print)
  • Right half of the stand (10 hours to print)
  • Left clamp (3 hours to print)
  • Middle clamp (1.5 hours to print)
  • Right clamp (3 hours to print)
    • Print settings: 5% infill
    layer height: 0.34
    number of shells: 1
    speed while extruding 80
    speed while traveling: 150
    turn on acceleration
    YES to raft and support material for overhangs Printable and ready to work. It could use a little bit of improvement so that the pieces fit better. Currently the pieces fit together well, but you can see the plastic starts cracking a little bit. This is does not degrade the stability of the stand, as it still holds the iPad just fine and should not break. It's really sturdy! I used ABS plastic. Have not tried PLA yet. Note: The left stand might not print correctly. The slot where the iPad fits might accidentally get filled by plastic with the currently uploaded S3G file. I had to use a saw to cut off part of the left stand, re-print a replacement piece, and glue it on. (the replacement piece is uploaded as LeftSlotReplace.s3g). If I figure out how to fix this print issue, I will re-upload a better version.

comments.text: Thanks for being as interested in this creation as you are. Some of you folks are much more in tune to 3D printing specifics than I am. For your information though, I make this on a CUBE 3D printer (by #D Systems), their second model. I did NOT have to use anything to brace or support it during printing as the glue I have to use holds it firmly. However, if you are having trouble keeping it stable I have used modelling clay to stabilize prints before. You have to be very careful applying it. Obviously you have to wait until the print is 1/2" or so in height. Then VERY  GENTLY put some wads of pliable modelling clay around the base of the bolt. This will hold it stable. I hope this helps. I had never really thought about it before, but I can see why and how using different brands of printers can create subtle problems that I did not have. For instance, on mine I do not have any precise setting for the clearance between the print head and the printing surface: I have to set it by 'feel'! But it is tight, a thin sheet of paper will barely slide in the gap.Good luck. Rob

comments.text: What kind of support did you use (if  any)? As my first attempt reached the smooth area of the bolt, it became unstable and subsequent layers were not aligned. Did you brace it? or maybe slow way down? Figured I get any tips you have before retrying. Great project. II love it...now if I can just reproduce it :-)
comments.author: Quedubya

comments.text:
What kind of printer do you have? It may depend on how your printer does x and y movement. For instance, my Solidoodle 2 has a bed that only moves along the z axis. if you have something like a Prusa i3, it might move from side to side enough to shift the print as momentum gets a hold of the tall unstable print. If that's the case, I'd say slow it down.
I've tried to print this once before and I'm trying again just now. I printed it at 20x because I thought the original model was tiny. Even while being bigger I dropped a loop or two on every thread so it was impossible to clean up. Now i'm printing at 40x and it has dropped only one loop and it looks easy enough to clean up. I'm sure my extrusion rate is too high and I'll tune that up after I print this screw. This is a great test to prove that you need to get that stuff locked in.
Another problem might be that I'm trying to print at .3mm layer height. That's not uncommon but for the original model and how fine it is in general, it might work better at .1 if you can get your printer to do it. Might be my next hurdle. I'll be sure to post a make as soon as I get a working one.
comments.author: Quedubya

description.text: This is a slightly stylized but easily printable jar for containing sundry items. Its design is inspired by the MakerBot logo and MakerGear's Cupcake Z Timing Pulley (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1084).

Fabricate with 3D printer. I have included the STL and SolidWorks files.
Note: The SolidWorks parts are 15% larger than the STL parts to ensure a "clean" print without overhangs.
The parts were sliced raftless in Skeinforge 007 at a layer height of 0.4mm and a feed rate of 23mm/s. The base printed at 1hr 14mins, the cupcake at 1hr 25mins and the cover at 25mins.
When the parts are complete, simply hotglue the cupcake onto the center of the cover and insert into the base for the completed assembly.
IDEA: At the end of the cupcake print, leave the excess plastic from the extruder nozzle at the top of the part. This piece would act to form the stem of the cherry top.

Rotated to better use the stronger XY plane.
No support material needed.

DISCLAIMER: This is a shameless copy from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22041/#instructions. === Usage Instructions === Print
Insert a nut in the big slot
Insert a 3mm nut in the little slot
Insert short 3mm screw in the little hole to hold the motor shaft
Put a nut on your Z axis threaded rod
Screw the rod into the captive nut through the bottom hole till it stops.
Tighten the nut below against the bottom.

description.text:
A classic impossible object, the ball in a box. My amazing mother used to carve these from a solid block of wood back in the day. My first ever 3d object i used 3d tin hope it prints!
-My Mom carved these in the 70's and she got it from a book about Native American crafts i wonder if they had CC?

I printed it on a Rep 2 at medium settings with a raft and support, 15% infill 2MM layer height and 3 shells. I seem to get layer adhesion problems randomly a couple of inches off the plate I think i might try Whpthomas's "rock-solid build plate pad up upgrade" as well as his extruder upgrade the black PLA is "SainSmart" brand from Amazon and so far about half way through the roll have had 3 or 4 dreaded "air prints", due to slight diameter irregularities (a couple mm. max) in the PLA that stop it from feeding, but when it does print it looks real nice... I have has good luck printing these on a rep 2 using Makerware to slice, No supports or raft. 3 shells, .15 layers and 50% infill. I love Whpthomas's ear raft supports http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38272 I add one under each span that touches the build plate and one under the ball. I gave one to my mom she liked it, yours would too...

author: KBIll

description.text:
IMPORTANT NOTICE
I have exams these days and experiments on this are delayed by now. I'll try to make a video of it working as soon as I finish them

"Y" joint to feed a single nozzle with two different filaments.   
With a bit of firmware tweaking it is possible to extrude multiple colours/materials with one nozzle.  
Material switching is still experimental, and needs a lot of tweaking. Cold retraction is needed to properly clean the tip, and distances need to be calibrated or you may end up trying to put two filaments in the same tubing section. It can be also a bit time-consuming.  
Anyway this has potential to be the grandfather of the multicolour printer of the future.  
The presented setting has been tested successfully on a Prusa Mendel i2 with a customized firmware, an E3D nozzle and two jonaskuehling extruders, generating the gcode with Kisslicer.

Ingredients
================= The setting is pretty simple, all you need is: -2 "Y" joint halfs, 3D printed.
-2xM5 bolts and nuts
-5xM3 bolts and nuts
-PTFE tubing
-A cutter
-Caution
-Faith Physical mounting
= You need to cut the PTFE tubing in a way that each tube has the shape of its place on the joint, AND all the inner surface of the joint is covered by PTFE. There is a photo with a red joint prototype up there that illustrates what you should get. The next thing you need to do is bolt everything together, very tightly. The tubing must be prepared to withstand the extruding force. The upper tubing goes to the extruders, and the lower one goes to the nozzle. Pretty straightforward, huh? The software part
= You are going to need some tweaking on your firmware to make your printer recognize that it has one nozzle with 2 stepper extruders.
I made that for you in this Marlin frankenstein I made from the last commit: https://github.com/gvJaime/Marlin/tree/DualFeed After that, you need to edit your extruder changing gcode routines to make your printer do what you want.
(Maybe, park extruder in a safe place, cool down, retract until out of the joint, heat up, extrude carefully to the tip, extrude a bit more, wipe, and go on with the print?) This last part needs more experimentation. Not to mix the two plastics is still a challenge.

comments.text:
To jpearce:
I cool down the filament to extract it entirely.
The experiments i have been making work this way:
I retract all the filament 1 out of the Y, and then extrude the filament 2, to the tip.
I don't have a place where the extruder can wipe himself, so I tried the "prime pillar" feature on KISSlicer to clean it out but thats just not enough.
The transition seems to be asintotic, in another words, it takes forever to COMPLETELY change from one filament to another.
The cooldown thing I came up with is a second guess... I'm not completely happy with it yet. I need more testing
To everyone else:
I don't get the cutting the filament thing. You mean to cut the filament on the base of the Y, and then let the other filament push down the rest?
Thats seems unstable to me, and the amount of plastic that fits in the section from the Y to the nozzle is ridiculously high.
You see, the Y has been design to make a HUGE retraction all the way up, and then a HUGE extrusion all the way down.
Because the PTFE covering all the inner surface, the filament won't trip anywhere, and it will go all the way down to the nozzle with no problem (the joint bowden-nozzle is intended to go flawlessly)
Referring to the dual single stepper extruder:
I though about it, and I will eventually put it in my branch of the firmware. I would like to design an extruder that is makeable with the non printable parts of the jonaskuehling extruder (i think is widely used, but by now this is just an idea)
The only extra non-printable part would be a servo, whose function will be to select which filament is going to be dragged by the bolt. It is unclear to me yet if the servo will withstand the forces of the springs, or will deliver enough force to clamp the filament against the bolt, or if this is too much work for a servo...
I'll keep experimenting, this escalated quickier than I thought.
comments.author: elgambitero

comments.text:
elgambitero
Regarding the cutting of filament:
Yesterday I changed colors by snipping off the old at the top of the printer and feeding in the new while a print was in progress. No "Y" gizmo was required because I switched them by hand, and gently pushed the new in behind the old...
The knurled bolt eventually runs out of #1 and grabs #2. This little stepper has no problem using the end of filament #2 to push whatever amount of #1 still remains in the hot-end below it.
A robot can easily take my place on my machine, and change filament as the printer prints. Two essential elements would be a cutter to snip off the old filament, and one "Y" leg or channel for each new color or material.
A third element is smart firmware which can predict exactly when to cut so it can properly manage and extrude the mixture of filaments entering and leaving the pipeline. Firmware seems like a potential problem but I know nothing about that stuff..
comments.author: elgambitero

comments.text:
It's funny that you say that. That's what I've been doing before coming up with this, making ABS parts with HIPS rafts by slapping the filament change gcode (M600) in between the two codes.
Cutting the filament in two parts seems uncompatible with retraction, which I use a lot. That wouldn't work for me.
Predicting the filament change is complicated because it is up to the slicer, and each slicer is programmed in a different way.
I think that the best approach here is to think of a way of cleaning the nozzle completely (and preferably fast) before inserting the next filament. I'm researching this way because, except the 2nd extruder (for now) it seems to be the option that requires less extra hardware.
I'll keep researching this, let's see where it gets.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
I'm sure it's what we've all been doing... OK.. Here's my ignorant thoughts about firmware creation.
First lay a raft of HIPS and measure the length of filament consumed. Remove that raft, measure out that same length on the spool of HIPS and mark the spot.
Measure the length between the knurled bolt and the top of the machine.
Subtract that second length from the mark on the spooled filament and make a "CUT HERE" mark.
If you cut it at that point during your next print and begin feeding ABS, the separation between the HIPS raft and the ABS part should be perfect...
I can only imagine how difficult or complicated it might be to program such a thing (I bought an Afinia and it does all the slicing and dicing automatically so I never needed to learn about that stuff.) but might the basic solution be as simple as inserting your calculated "cut factor" into the code? And when the program reaches that point it flashes a light, which means "Cut Now".
I can say that from a practical hardware / mechanical point of view it wouldn't be too difficult to switch filament seamlessly, without all the pausing, moving, retraction and withdrawing the current state of art gcodes insist on doing. It may require some powerful components, perhaps even air cylinders, for drive-bearing pressure or for cutting filaments, but if that's what it takes then so be it.
comments.author: elgambitero

comments.text:
That would make sense. Cutting the filament is not the approach I'm making here, but I'm gonna share my thoughts on it...
First of all, the method would be good, but not at all perfect, because at melting temperatures, the filament not only pushes, but mixes. Extra extrusion would be needed to go from (for example) completely red to completely blue. It is also needed with my system.
The cutting decision is up to the slicer. The easiest way I would have to approach this is modifying skeinforge: we could make a post-proc-.... WAIT!
We could make a post process not only for skeinforge, but for every slicer! It would read the distance remaining for the next change of filament, and enter a cutting gcode on the proper spot, so when the time of changing material comes, the cut will be at the tip. I'm writing this as it comes to my mind.
Also, I see a flaw there, and it is that the amount of extruded material before being able to switch must be less than the distance from the cutter and the nozzle.
The extra hardware seems to be hard to design, setup, and mantain...
But as I said, it's not the approach I'm making here.
I'll try to post a video of it working soon, so functioning its clearer. My descriptions aren't very lucid at the time.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Your description is fine... as good as they get with the written word.
A cutting system won't be perfect. The color mixing did occur to me.
Practically speaking, how much mixing is there? When I change color, a mixed string of perhaps 5cm at 0.5mm diameter is created. That volume of mix is noticeable but still rather small.
Perfection is expensive. If this were my project I'd concentrate on getting a basic prototype in working order and refine it as time goes on. I have worked with plastic and even with the retraction method that melt barrel is not perfectly clean. At the least it needs to be purged. And even then it's not perfect if one examines closely.
If using the filament cutting method, one could accept the mixed color and just take a moment to quickly purge that wasted 5cm off to the side of the part. No longer a perfectly seamless system, but still far less trouble prone than the retraction method...
Yes. I now realize my error calculating where to mark cuts. One proper point should be at the nozzle.... but the nozzle / hot-end is better defined with a "volume" (of partially melted plastic) rather than simply a length of filament, and doing it right would have complicated my attempt to express my idea.. so nothing was lost..
I'm also thinking.... about the mechanics of a cutting process.... but in my experience "virtual" mechanics and reality are most often at odds. You have to actually make prototypes and test them to see what works and what doesn't. And after the long string of total failures, you hope for new inspiration. It takes devotion and time, two things I don't have regarding this dual extrusion project. I'm more of a practical person than a artist and see little use for it so my heart's not in it...
The cost and difficulty of designing, building and maintaining the cut-system certainly are potential drawbacks but real the question is which system is ultimately serves people better. I can't predict that. I don't know what fellow makers want or what they would do with it. I only know what I want.
,,,,,,,,,
A few weeks ago I asked about comment editing problems and the Thingiverse staff is in the process of writing their own program to take the place of the weak and very problematic "disqus comments" software currently in use here. Meanwhile do what I do...be careful and proof-read..
comments.author: elgambitero

comments.text:
This is taking an interesting shape...
So the "filament cutting material switching system" would be:
Some kind of extruder with dual feed, and a cutter at the entrance of the common section to the nozzle. A post processing script manages to paste the cutting gcode on the proper point of the gcode, and material switch just goes on the fly.
I'm still seeing two big flaws: first, no retraction is possible; and second, if the extruder happens to jam, a small bit of cut filament may get in there, with no easy way to get it out, due to no retraction.
I'm going to keep researching on the big retraction method, and if something good enough about the cutting method comes to my mind, I'll share it here.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
In my mind, ideally, all the cutting and switching wouldn't even happen on the printer. Instead it could be a self contained, remote feeding system. It could be fed by any number of spools while having only one outlet.
The mechanics of a separate feed-machine would not be restricted to the low weights allowed, low power and very little space available in and around a 3D printer. And its only task is to cut one filament and insert some other into its outlet tube on command.
The printer is unchanged. It needs to manage only one incoming filament, just like usual. The feeder might be attached to any printer as long as the software is accessible for modifications.
You mention a flaw.. the necessity of extraction... and I still don't get that. Are you referring to a cutting system? If so, why or how is extraction always necessary? Perhaps we have differing definitions of the word extraction..
comments.author: elgambitero

comments.text: It would be nontrivial, but what about moving the Y junction inside the hot end? Then you could extrude A, B, or an arbitrary combination of A+B in different ratios. There would not be much wastage if you just extrude the interface when switching inputs as the junction is already right near the tip, and you woudn't have to worry about reversing, cutting, etc.

comments.text:
I don't see where retraction would be necessary... or I don't understand why it needs to be.
The trick would be to cut the filament in such a way that the new one can push down on the old filament without needing a retraction.
For instance, lets say a 1 cm diameter hole-punch is centered at the crotch of the "Y". and it cuts a round 1cm hole. When it cuts, it clips all 3 legs in the "Y". So, there's a 1/2 cm gap of emptiness in all 3 legs...
Creating an "emptiness" in the feed channel is the whole purpose of retraction. It provides the new filament a clear pathway to begin feeding. This round punch could do it (in theory anyway).
Lenbok: I knew someone must have thought of this... it's so simple.
I don't know if using 2 independent pressure bearings with a single knurled drive-gear is a new one or not, but probably not. A lot of ideas go nowhere and die for a lots reasons, but are reincarnated by the uninformed.
comments.author: th0mass

comments.text: retraction is needed in printing already to have a better print result. it does not related with this particular design,
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
th0mass
Well, yes. Some retraction is required for good quality. Without it the nozzle will drool when extrusion pauses to move the nozzle across the platform to continue printing.
I watch the stepper-shaft on this Afinia's extruder and can see it retract the filament a step or two on almost every pass. It sometimes simultaneously drops the build platform one or two layers to (I guess) help break the "string" so it doesn't leave trails.
But if I understand elgambitero's Y-concept, the intention of retraction is not to prevent drooling. It is to retract the #1 filament completely up and out of the hot end and empty it to allow the #2 filament entrance into the "Y".
comments.author: th0mass

comments.text:

If filament #2 is pushing #1, whatever remains of #1 filament below the extruder cannot be pulled up... or retracted. So, the quality of the print would suffer.
On my printer that would be 3cm of wasted purge, assuming the cutting / switching "black-box" is sitting atop the printer..

one more thing.. You've mentioned retracting but that may not be necessary.

comments.text: This is a cool idea -- and I think you are on to something very valuable. Thanks! Question - Why are you waiting for the cool down? I think this would make printing take forever.  Why not instead - on each material change - retract filament 1 hot until out of y - it can cool in the tube,  park extruder in a safe place and then push filament 2 through until it has cleared out the head of material 1 - then go and print after a wipe. If you run the experiment once or twice with your materials you can set the time constant.  If you are clever with a slightly different dump and wipe zone with each head - you can use the dump as a wall to do the wipe of the other material. To make this really work we need to go to thinner filament and smaller - lower volume extruder heads so there is not as much waste.

title: Sports Model Flying Saucer for dualstrusion

description.text: Industrial production of two tone flying saucers was taking a while, due to the need to separately print the hull and the insert. Now, with an accelerated firmware, you can have the entire saucer ready to glue together and invade planets, in less than 4 hours. This is the same model as the Two Tone Flying Saucer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11996) but prepared for dualstrusion. Also top half and bottom half are printed simultaneously (on a Replicator)

Merge the dual_hull and dual_insert  STL files for dualstrusion. Load your filament for the hull and inserts into the appropriate extruders.
Print!
Glue together top and bottom half. Use bits of filament in the registration holes to keep everything lined up.

description.text: More of the same

A portrait of Patrick- the Coney Island USA House Manager. This was scanned in two parts, then joined in Meshlab. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is my 21st century photo booth project. This is scanned with my Heavy Duty Lazy Susan for Full Body Scanning thing (see thingiverse.com/thing:28454) and ReconstructMe software (http://reconstructMe.net). I printed with 2 shells, 20% infill and support. His costume was a little challenging to print, but I'm still pretty pleased with the result.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/0Y5lhNEHtKF

I've been working for a couple of weeks on a RepRap Arduino Mega shield. I've got a mix of early generation 2 electronics, a few home-made single sided generation 3 stepper boards, and old arduino with a screw-terminal shield and a brand-new arduino mega. I designed myself a version of an arduino mega shield to connect the gen3 stepper boards using the 10-pin IDC cables, and it might be useful for anyone transitioning between generations of electronics. Features:
  • Single-sided for PCB for easier home-made boards
  • 5 stepper driver headers - x,y,z,a,b - should match existing gen3 electronics.
  • (future-proof?) UI interface header that *should* match gen4 electronics.
  • Heater 10-pin IDC (to plug in MOSFET driver board later) - should be able to drive a reprap setup with 1 or 2 extruders/ heated bed without an additional extruder board.
  • I2c header as per standard boards
  • Optional extra 3-pin headers for digital in\out and analog in : +5v, GND, and data pin. This makes it easy to add temperature sensors, kill switches, extra limit switches, etc (I'm only using the min endstops).
    • You can treat this as more of a prototyping board, and solder as many headers/pins as you need: I bought a dozen 50-pin headers, so I filled mine up. I'm only expecting to use one or two of the analog inputs as temperature sensors for now. NOTE that the +5v/Gnd/Signal headers for the digital and analog pins are directly connected to the internal arduino 5V supply. DO NOT run anything major off these headers. I was only planning to add simple data switches (digital input from high/low), simple thermistor circuits (Analog input) and potentially a small servo (9g micro servo) off these I/O pins - so I didn't pay much attention to them. If you are running any further circuits, use a separate power supply! (all RepRap boards have separate 12v PSU headers anyway).

My build went well. I 'tinned' the copper pads (using some plumbing flux and a tiny bit of solder), which made the soldering a bit easier. Using a tip (from ladyada?) I converted some standard header pins to some through-pins by pushing them through using the flat on a pair of pliers, three or 4 at a time. Once I'd lengthened the pins, I could put them through from the top of the board into the arduino and check the alignment. I left the pins partially pushed in to maintain the position, and soldered a single pin from each row.
This held them in place when I removed the mega and soldered the rest. Top Tip : apply the silkscreen layer before you solder the board up. I didn't and had to write all my pin numbers on with a sharpie. Some pictures of my build in progress:
http://renoirsrants.blogspot.com/2010/06/renoirs-mega-shield-built.html If you're looking for the arduino mega shield, pins only, I've got some eagle files here:
http://sites.google.com/site/renoirsrants/reprap/arduinomegashield?pli=1 EDIT:
Updated with thicker traces and ground plane, and 0.3mm centre drills.
Should be easier to home-etch.

This is part of my Baby-Huey large format 3D printer project.
http://nerdipedia.com/tiki-index.php?page=huey
It may also be of use for other projects. Huey is a work in progress so the assembly has never been used in earnest. It was printed and assembled and seems to do what is it is supposed to do. This thing uses 4 skate bearing to travel along a 25.4 (or 25mm) square tube. It is not stable until it is attached to its mates and all four are supported by threaded rod (M6 but imperial might work). Stepper motors or idler pulleys can be fitted to two sides.
The steppers are mounted via an adapter plate. The round shaft is 12mm. I've changed to a simpler two bearing thing and have no plans to use this part any more.

The main thing is in two parts - each holds two bearings.
The parts are tightened against the shaft using M3 screws. You can print 8mm dia pins to hold the bearings in place or some other kind of 8mm rod. There is removable support in the thing.
The things that look like handles are support which can be removed or not.
So don't panic if you break it accidentally.

comments.text: A lot of it has to do with the object you're scanning. Like I said on your other scan, the Digitizer works best for objects that are more than 6 inches tall and about 4 inches wide. Things that are made up of thin narrow parts like this and the doll can be difficult to scan well. Think of it this way, when you're looking at the preview of the video view - to get the most details out of the scan, the object you're scanning needs to take up the most of that screen area as possible. title: Fujica X-mount to Sony E-Mount (NEX) adapter

description.text:
Fujica X-mount (circa 1970s-1985, not to be confused with the confusingly similarly-named 201X-era Fujifilm X-mount) to E-Mount (Sony NEX, A7/r, A6000, etc) adapter.  
Based off measurements made from the 3 Fujica X-mount lenses I have (all 3rd party, one Rokinon and two X-Kominar) and my Sony A7 camera.   
I'm not sure how well the measurements adapt to allowed manufacturing tolerances for either mount given the limited amount of samples, but it should be easy to modify the OpenSCAD source to match if you run into fit issues with the current values.  
There is no explicit locking mechanism on the Fujica X-mount side, but between the tight fit of the thread rings and the aperture lock, this hasn't been a problem for me.  When printed with high-infill in ABS the adapter has been working out really well.  Use caution if using this with highly valued lenses.

comments.text: Just in case anyone thinks this is a good idea to use, 3D printed plastic is not food safe. The dyes in it can contain substances you do not want to eat on top of the fact that it cannot be kept clean. Contact with the hot end and other printer parts may contaminate the filament during production. After production the small layers in the print give bacteria nice places to live and cannot be effectively cleaned.

description.text: I recently lost an eBay auction for a novelty Three Mile Island mug (see the first pic). Much to my dismay, there was another human on the planet who insisted on paying more than $30 for a humorous piece of nuclear history. Luckily for me, I have an expensive machine that can churn out plastic-based trash at an astonishingly slow rate! After 30 minutes of sloppy modeling and 3 hours of printing, I present the not-so-official Three Mile Island novelty mug!

If you are just making this as a wacky pen-holder, use 10% infill and 1 additional shell. If you are attempting to make it watertight, you probably want to do 100 infill and 3 shells. However, drinking from this might be as safe as drinking water from Three Mile Island itself, so do it at your own risk.  
In both cases, you should print with exterior supports. if you're using ReplicatorG, disable the base and interface supports so that the cup has a nice, smooth bottom.

author: FozBuild

title: iPhone tripod mount with quick release

description.text: After years of going to Maker Faire and seeing Arc Attack, I was frustrated by my Video of them playing - in an effort to fix this, I decided to build a tripod mount just for Maker Faire. Because, I used this on my phone and connected it to a Monopod the iPhone needed to be able to be disconnected very easily in the event somebody called. Since there were no quick release iPhone mounts I had to build it myself The quick release and design worked incredibly well, however the video I took turned out to be pretty bad. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I0--48xi928

Tools:
CA glue
Laser cutter
wood glue Parts:
M3 x 50 mm Screw
M3 x 95 mm threaded rod
3 M3 nuts
1 1/4-20 threaded insert
5-10 washers
6mm flat material that can be laser cut - I used baltic birch
1 inch compression spring The assembly is pretty simple and self explanatory once you cut out there parts. They just need to be glued together using the wood glue to form two separate parts, the base and the hinged quick release. Once that is done, follow these instructions:
1) screw 1/4-20 insert into bottom of base, this will be hard to do in baltic birch so it may require making the hole bigger. if it is MDF it should be fine with current hole.
2) use the 95mm threaded rod as the hinge pin between the two parts and add two washers and two nuts to either end of the threaded rod to hold it in place.
3) Add the M3 x50 screw vertically with the head of the screw facing up. It will go through the hole in the hinge and the base, before putting it through the base, put the compression spring with a washer on either side between the base and hinged quick release (see picture).
4) Add a washer and nut to the bottom of the M3 screw and test the fit with an iPhone.
5) Add additional washers below spring to ensure appropriate tension
6) Once set to satisfaction, apply CA glue to M3 Nuts to lock them in place

remixed_from.author: mrbenbritton
remixed_from.title: Smily Cookie cutter and stamp, With Improved Script!

description.text:
You have a set of number cookie cutters at home, you may even have the normal operations + - x /. What is you have an irrational urge to transcend the ordinary and let your imagination take you to the golden cookie! This is the set for you. It includes some of the most opoular numbers not included in the standard 0-9 set as well as a few of the less common variables and the integral opperator. The set contains:
e, i, pi, phi, Sigma (big and little), i, sqrt(-1), integral sign. If you feel I have missed something out I may do requests if you ask nicely and promise to post pictures.

To get all the cutters in one handy lump, download the zip file. It is way down near the bottom of the list and I can't re-order them. To make a geeky maths cutter, first download your choice of symbol (or download the zip file to get all of them in one handy package) Print it then make cookies. This site has a great recipe: thehungryhousewife.com/2009/10/sugar-cookie-and-icing-tips.html . Roll thin, cut out, bake and eat. Don't forget to make bad jokes about imaginary cookies! If you want to create your own cookie cutter you will need:
OpenSCAD
An image editor that can export to DXF (I use inkscape) The cookie cutters are generated by the CookieCutter2.scad OpenSCAD script. They use different layers of a DXF to make different parts of the cutter CC
This becomes the blade of the cutter
Supports
This is where you draw things to hold floating sections of the blade (the hole in the 0)
Lines
This defines areas to remove the flange from (the hole in the 0)
Stamp
Not used for this set, see Thing 32431 Have a look at the two SVG files included here for examples of how the layers work. Create your image and massage all layers into a workable form and save as a DXF (look at repraprip.blogspot.co.nz/2011/05/inkscape-to-openscad-dxf-tutorial.html for instructions) You will need to edit the CookieCutter2.scad file to open your dxf. Run the script to generate the cutter, it may take 10 minutes or so depending on your machine. Export the STL and start printingyour own cutters. Don't forget to post them here!

comments.text:
2 things:
(a) you might check your slicer program (e.g. Cura) for the "combing" setting -- it tells the print-head to [move / not-move] across empty areas when it's not actually extruding. For a cookie-cutter, which by definition has lots of empty area, it might help to have the print-head moving over printed (perimeter) areas rather than directly across.
(b) you might also look at your retraction settings. Whenever the head stops printing to move somewhere else, there's a step where it pulls the filament back IN a little before it moves - so there's not a bit of leftover material that it drags along with it to the new 'start printing again' location. There're actually a number of settings related to retraction - like how much is the minimum extrusion before it would retract, whether it does a "Z-hop", etc.... I'm also new at this, but from what I understand, this is all about getting rid of 'stringing'.
Good luck!

description.text: Made a clamp to hold in place lamp socket due to original bulb braket lip broke.
Side tanks for the ThunderTiger Neptune SB-1

print part 1 2x (one for each side)
print part 2 or 3 2x
Table 2 is the mid section of the tank
Table 3 is the mid section of the tank with a lid. These fit the Maxi size Kinder Suprise egg containers. When you're done LOLing,... these make great watertight containers, and can easily house an Arduino Mini or Nano and a 9V battery.
Put 2 by 200mm threaded rod in de 4 holes of eache large piece and slide on the slim mountpieces and caps from part 2.
Put the tanks on a surface next to your SB-1, mark the height of the large 5mm holes in the mountpieces of the tank onto the hull of the SB-1 by drawing a line. This is the part of the (wet) hull that houses the dead ballast. on that line, mark 2 points at 13.7mm from each other (so 7.25mm from the center of the line) and mirror this on the other side of the hull.
Put a 5mm rod through the holes and attach the tanks to that. put locking rings at the end of the rods to secure the tanks (there are niches in the mountpieces to accomodate these, and a hole going from the bottom up so you can screw them tight with a hex key).

title: RC plane with brushless motor - ABS plastic and PS Foam hybrib

description.text: 24 Nov - Updates to the full ABS version with a 1400mm wing span also available http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33732 06 Nov - Slight tweaks to the rudder and tail fin... nothing that could not be done during the fitting process, just a minor refinement. 04 Nov - To avoid any confusion I have reduced the nunmber of files here and published a separate model for the full ABS version. 1 Nov - Updated nose cone / engine mount. 30 Oct - Instructions updated. Based on a cub / trainer design aircraft, this thing is under construction to be a fully printable remote control aircraft. More pics and the rest of the design to come as soon as I get a couple of parts from Hong Kong to complete the fuselage. The default pic is the assembled hull plus wings, pending reinforcement of the nose section with carbon tissue and then the heat shrink skin over the rest of the body.

30 Oct - V3 rear stabiliser and matching rudder added. Increased surface area and more aerodynamic profile.
27 Oct - added a nose cone to go with the tail section.. no more foam .. !!! big hooray here.. ! also have added a more aerodynamic version of the stabiliser and control surface.
I have tested all of the components for this model, its incredibly strong easy to fly and forgiving in a crash. 
AUW is around 520g, depending on motor, esc and battery selection. Version 2 fuselage, with an ABS nose and tail section adds around 200g.. (am refinihng these prints), but is still within the power range for the standard motor and prop.
Have trashed 2 foam models in flight and crash testing the of the components, none of which have broken or failed. 
Always happy to see someone with much more experience than me at this take it to a new level.. :).
There is a lot of material in the main structural component of the plane, the battery and servo housing, as experience has taught me that its this part of the structure which cops most of the force in a crash. While the designs can always be refined, this is the structure which will retain the battery and without ripping the electronics out in the event of a sudden stop.
Please note the instructions are a guide... they will include pics of each stage and notes where required re print settings.
The printed parts are generally designed to fit tight, so some drilling or trimming is required to get a the appropriate fit, along with a few spots of super glue.
You will need some familiarity with the process of building  and wiring models of this type. Links are included in the instructions for the parts I have used, with variation for performace, battery life and AUW easily accommodated.
All parts are printed using ABS.
Good luck.. and enjoy.. :)

description.text:
Designed in SketchUp.
This quad can fold up into a 12" x 8" x 3" envelope.
Extended, this quad becomes a 450 sized frame.

The wood used in this build are 1/2" square dowels.
Each boom arm are 6.25" long.
Each motor mount is attached with the foot with M3-25 screws and nuts.
Each boom arm is sandwiched between two frame plates and attached with M3-25 screws and nuts. (Make sure the slotted sides are facing out.)
The battery box (below the copter) and the brackets for a NAZA are attached with M3-12 screws and nuts.
Motors are attached to the motor brackets with M3-8 screws.
ESCs are ziptied to the boom arms. The quadcopter comes in at 30oz with battery.

description.text:
The world needs a New Hero :
The French Maker! le FabShop organises the first PARIS MAKER FAIRE (June 21st and 22nd). http://www.makerfaireparis.com/ To celebrate that, our creative director, Samuel N. Bernier, designed a very clever and cute version of the MAKER FAIRE ROBOT. It is fully articulated, with a total of 11 axis, printed all at once. If you liked our little elephant, you will LOVE this FFF 3D printing exploit! See you in Paris for the most stylish Maker Faire ever.

Just print it on his but and work the axis gently once removed from the build platform.   
The roBot can easily be scaled up, but we never tried scaling it down.   
It takes 2 hours to print in standard mode.   
Enjoy!

comments.text:
Just printed this after rebuilding my delta printer with an E3Dv6 and a DIY geared extruder using eSun PLA+. I ran at 80mm/s, .2mm layer, supports, 30% infill, heated bed, and the printer took 1 hr, 45 m.
It came out perfectly, all joints broke loose with minimal effort. Wow. My first attempt at this several months ago was 9 attempts and no perfect successes. What a difference a well dialed-in machine can make!
FWIW, my printer is a Folgertech Kossel 2020, sliced and printed with Simplify3D.
edit
Wow, I made another of the 65pc on a scratch-built reprap Cartesian printer: .3mm layer, 30mm/s speed, 30% infill, no supports, no geared extruder, eSun PLA+ filament on a heated bed. This took 2h, 31m. Again, popped it off the bed and all of the joints pulled free in seconds. I am having a lucky day.

This was a great print thank you. I learned an enormous amount about my printer and my slicer.
Printer Kossel Mini
Tried printing 3 times using Slic3r no go. First time using Cura perfect 0.15 layer 3 shells 50mm/s.
Went back and adjust Silc3r setting. The keys were a fixed wall 0.42, .2 layer 3 horizontal 3 vertical shells, 50mm/s, brim 4 mm with support. Finally, external perimeters first. Then just used a tool like an awl to clean up around the joints all worked perfectly. Thanks again!

comments.text: I've printed the Robot_Maker_Faire_65pc.stl four times on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Generation using different colors of PLA filament. My printer settings were: standard resolution (i.e., 10% infill, 2 shell, 0.20 mm layer height) and rafts on but supports off. All four printed beautifully--the number of movable joints is really incredible--however, for two of the prints, the leg joints (at the hip) were fused. I tried to delicately free them but to no avail (I broke the legs right off). Note: I also had fused arms on a few prints but I was able to successfully free these. In reading other comments below, this appears to be a common problem. I'll keep experimenting and post again if I improve my process.

comments.text:
Almost managed to print one successfully : one leg ( the right one ) broke up, look like it got welded to the body, somehow. Well, now it's glued standing up.
And I think about everything that could go wrong to print it did : First try was a completely welded mess ( except for the left arm ).
Then I recalibrated my printer ( printrbot simple maker's edition ) and I kept bumping parts mid print. Even when printing on a raft.
Then I had the extruder stepper overheat one hour into the print.
So I learned how to triple check my calibrations, how to tune down the power going to the steppers, set up a fairly slow acceleration, and I reminded myself to use some threadlock on the hobbler.
( Not perfect yet, I still have some parts where the filament look like it's missing. Not enough extruding, I guess... )
I used a 4mm brim, with 0.20 layer height.
I think by scaling up a little bit ( 120% maybe ), it could have worked....

description.text: This tower is a good tool for those of us who have an uncontrollabe sweet tooth. Personally, I have caught myself eating way to much candy before, during and after Halloween. To solve my candy problem, I made this candy holder. This holder has seven tiers, each of which correlates to the seven days in a week. So on Sunday of every week, you can fill every tier with as much candy as will fit on them. Then, on every day of the following week you can eat the candy that is in one of the tiers. That way, you can hopefully control the amount of candy you eat everyday!

To make this tower, you simply print out this design using a laser cutter. Then you place one of the squares on the bottom (so that the hexagons have a flat top and bottom line) and glue two of the triangle pieces on the east and west sides of the square using wood glue. The you take another square and rotate it 90 degrees so that the hexagons on it have a differnt orientation (the pointed ends are facing up as shown in the close up of the square piece). If you notice, when you rotate the squares by 90 degrees on every tier, after you finish the tower and look down the hexagonal holes, you see a cool shrinking and alternating pattern. After that, you glue two more of the triangles using wood glue but this time, put the triangles on the north and south end of the square. That way you get a more asthetically pleasing pattern with the sides of the tower alternating from being open to being blocked. Note: be careful while gluing the wood pieces together and make sure you follow the instructions that are written on the wood glue.

A pogo spring connector holder for on board programming/debugging of microcontrollers.

If you are an electronics hobbyist who develops PCBs, this thingy is for you!
As one who designed quite a bunch of PCBs with micro-controllers, I often encounter situations where there is no room for adding a jtag connector, or a connector is needed only once for programming, and hence its a waste of space and parts to mount it just for a single programming sequence.
The solution for that is preparing bare touch contacts on the pcb, and use pogo spring pins connector to hold into the pcb and perform the programming. But what happens if we need to do some debugging as well? We can not just hold the connector manually throughout the entire process, we need something to hold it there. This is where the #D printer comes handy! Instructions:

  • Apart from printed part to will need:
    a. M3 screw and nut,
    b. M5 screw, a washer, and 2 nuts.
    c. A pogo spring adapter such as this one: http://www.ebay.com/itm/250805614388?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1439.l2649

  • Print the the 2 parts!

  • If needed, using 3mm and 5mm drill, make sure the screw holes are wide enough.

  • If you are using the proposed pogo spring adapter, use a utility knife to carve the adapter head do it will fit the holder.

  • just look at the attached image for clarity.
    • Happy printing!

The lovely and talented Mrs. Zheng3's passion is gardening, and, vinelike, her hobby-but-so-much-more extends tendrils throughout our homestead every spring. Ere long the house and yard will be overrun and four months hence we will smother under bushels of heirloom tomatoes. Yesterday the garage was infiltrated by a new storage unit, soon to be stocked with chrysanthemum powder, mushroom compost, and myriad other eye-of-newtish polypropylene sacks with contents beyond my ken. Alas! The shelving arrived unshod, and past experience tells me that corner of the garage will most certainly flood with the first significant rain of the season, so to the printer we go to keep the unit's legs rust-free.
This footing is designed for an Edsal Storage Rack, but will likely fit others with some finagling of scale. These racks are rated for two tons, so I recommend printing these footings at high infill.

Yet another overwhelming silly weapon-wannabe. These banana nunchucks let you bring your favorite carb/proteins to the gym while flexing biceps at your fellow Kickboxercisers.
Please note that these Banana Nunchucks work better with straighter* bananas.
*non-gender, -as-a-ruler

• Print parts, link the tops and bottoms with thin bungee cords.
  • Connect both bananas with the meanest looking chain you can find at the local sundry.
    • Disclaimer
    The user assumes all responsibility if he/she decides to engage in any life threatening activities while using the Banana Nunchucks.
  • Do not carry these openly into a bank, fast food joint or federal building. You should not carry them concealed either, unless you have a valid Concealed Banana Nunchuck Carrying license (Form 1206).
  • Do not go thru any airport, or board a plane with them (You can, however, hand carry just the bananas*)
  • Do not walk into a cage full of hungry gorillas wielding these nunchucks**.
  • Fruit consumption and usage of banana skins for fun/profit post-Banana-Nunchuck-wielding is beyond the scope of this object; please check with respective grocery for relevant terms, conditions and disclaimers.
    • *The TSA website may or may not have current information on non-metal-chain-connected-bananas.
    **especially if the gorillas are the ones wielding the nunchucks.

These sleeves are designed to go on a 9mm Bearing as used on the X-axis of the Ormerod. Their purpose is to be pushed on to the bearing. You then trim the excess so the bearing and sleeve are the same size. Then use the Sleeved Bearing to replace the 10mm Bearing fitted to the Y-axis. This 10mm Bearing can then be fitted to the X-axis. The sleeves are in a group of 3, so hopefully you should be able to print as least one reasonable one out of the three.  
This is to help people that don't have Lathes at their immediate disposal.

I have a Replicator with 2 heads. The stock filament spool holders bugged me. Hard to get the spool off of the holder, the two spools stuck out different amounts, and the holders came off of the machine when I tried to get the spools off.
Here's my attempt at fixing those problems.
The pieces go together with #8 sheet metal screws.

description.text:
Started from an existing RaspberryPi enclosure and modified it to be able to contain as well the Adafruit PiTFT Mini Kit (http://www.adafruit.com/products/1601). It may be a bit hard to close, but it stays tight in place afterward.
Also you can print the Support (you'll need two of them), to hold the case at a comfy 30 degrees.

I printed mine on a Makerbot Replicator 2 on low res with default settings. No need for support neither rafts while printing.
You can optionally print 2 of the Support (separate file) to keep the Enclosure standing at a comfy 30 degrees.

author: lotos

description.text:
Modified mount clips for Ikea Dioder lighting to enable strips to be affixed internally in the Replicator frame.
This model is based on a combination of designs from txoof (Thing 98691) and hullo3d (Thing 32373).  I wanted the LED strips to be INTERNAL to the Replicator frame, and light the build platform from both top and front, maximizing the output from the strips, protecting them from accidental damage, reducing glare, and maintaining the aesthetic of the machine.
Most importantly, this method does not interfere with any method of enclosing the build platform with plexi so that you can still use any clips or mounts on the top, front and sides of the machine.

1) Print 8 clips either individually or use plated file with no infill and single wall to help aid flexibility. These aren't heavy duty parts, so you don't need much to hold the LED strips. Depending on tolerances, you might need to slide clips onto Dioder strips from the end - they can be a tight fit.
2) Cut one side of the adhesive foam provided by Ikea in half, apply each segment to the flat side of the clip.
3) Position LED strips to the left and right short sides of the front and sides, sliding clips to adjust for opening, carefully positioning wired ends above Replicator (drive rail) shafts.
4) Follow existing wiring to snake Dioder leads through existing Makerbot wire clips so that they reach underneath machine, use twist ties to take up slack.
5) Mount transformer and 4-way plug under Replicator deck frame using remaining foam strips.

title: First Full Size Handbag 3d Printed with Dress & Shoes made with a Replicator!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This handbag has an outside pocket for your smart phone. Put a bit of Velcro(TM) on the smartphone to secure it in the handbag. The handle may be removed and replaced with a flexible shoulder strap.
I will put the shoulder strap on 3dPrintFileMarket.com for download in a couple days. The dress and the shoes in the picture above will be available on 3d Print File Market before October 31, 2014. This is not just another 3d printing website. It is the home of The Original Technology Accelerator App that will change the world.

To print the handbag with soluble support and ABS as one complete handbag with no assembly required, print the following files; 1. The handbag's support - nhandbag1pciii.stl 2. The handbag - phandbag1pciii(1).stl 3. The handle - branchhandle.stl 4. The handle's support - negbranchhandle.stl 5. Bolt that holds handle to handbag, oil threads with vegetable oil - handbagbolt.stl 6. Nut that retains bolt that holds handle to handbag - handbagnut.stl To print the handbag with a single extruder 3D Printer with ABS, you do not need to choose the "support" setting on your 3D printer. Print the following files, remove the designed supports with a sharp hobby knife and glue the pieces together by putting an acetone-ABS slurry on both pieces and pressing them together. To make acetone-ABS slurry, put tiny flakes of ABS in a dropper bottle of acetone. Shake the dropper bottle periodically for 24 hours. After gluing the pieces together, allow 24 hours for the glue to set before using; 1. bagphholder(1).stl - holds cell phone in handbag. You can secure cell phone either by using a bit of Velcro(TM) with the fuzzy loop side on the handbag so that the hard hooks won't damage your clothing if you use the handbag without a cell phone. You may also secure your cell phone by gluing a bit of sponge to the handbag to wedge the cell phone securely against the handbag. 2. bodyii(1).stl - main body of the handbag. 3. femalelatch.stl - female latch that secures handbag's lid. Print with the largest flat surface on the print surface. 4. handbagbolt.stl - bolt that holds handle to handbag. Oil the bolt with vegetable oil so that it screws on smoothly without breaking because the fit is a little tight. 5. handbagnut.stl - nut that retains bolt that holds handle to handbag. 6. handlewtabs.stl - handbag's handle. 7. hingecap.stl - keeps lid in place. 8. holeforpeg.stl - retains handle to screw. 9. lidii(2).stl - handbag's lid. 10. malelatch.stl - male latch that secures handbag's lid. Print with prongs flat on print surface. 11. topedgeii(1).stl - the top of the handbag that the lid secures to.

A fan duct for a cooling fan.  
The OpenSCAD file is very easy to adjust to any size of fan. and things like length of the cone and whether the cone is cut at an angle can be adjusted as well.  
It is just something I put together quickly because I could not find the one I used previously, so some of the code is still not that nice, perhaps I will put up a revised version later.  
Hope someone will find this thing useful :-).  
The idea of this fan is to just attach a fan to it, and then just hot glue it to your printer, very fast and easy, though you might want a more elegant solution in the long run :-P.

title: Claptrap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a model of the Borderlands character Claptrap. The wheel rolls and requires some assembly.

Note: This piece was made on a Makerbot Replicator and using 1.75mm black ABS plastic.

  • Open the file "the claptrap parts" in the Replicator G program.

  • Rotate the piece so the Claptrap's head is on the platform.

  • Generate the G-Code and begin the build. (This will take a while to print.

  • Using acrylic glue, insert the arms into the holes that match its size.

  • Glue the axle to the rounded side of ONE leg bracket.

  • Place the wheel over the axle and glue the second leg bracket onto the other side of the axle.

  • Insert the two leg brackets into the matching holes and glue it together.
    • Note: If a part breaks or is lost, create it using the appropriate attached file. (For example, if the axle breaks, download the "axle" file and build that.) "the claptrap parts" is all the parts in one file.

description.text: I adjusted the original adapter to have a slightly tighter hole for the end of the Lightning cable. I also added another part - the cable lock. It allows the cable to bend while also keeping it tucked in nice and tidy below the dock. See it here: http://a.wholelottanothing.org/2012/10/lightning-adapters-in-the-elevation-dock.html

I printed the parts on a Makerbot Replicator with a layer thickness 0.2mm, 100% fill using PLA. I found some screws from my box of many that fit the holes available in the dock for the cable lock down part. I have no idea what size they are.

A slightly altered Extruder Drive Block for the Ormerod 3D printer.  
After hearing of people experiencing their supplied extruder block beginning to wear through I remodelled the feed from a 50mm diameter to a 75mm diameter.  
Hopefully slightly reducing the pressure against the top of the feed channel.  
I also extended the support clip a bit where it clips over the X axis. I had experience of the original coming unclipped.
